process. First, it simply restarted by nailgun-agent to change
node's ID. And then it gets restarted by fix-configs-on-startup
after it fixes mcollective's configuration file.

provisioning problems when node's boot process is delayed. The
simpe workaround is to run fix-configs-on-startup by nailgun-agent
and exclude fix-configs-on-startup from rc.local.

subject: oidc: fix OpenID Connect authorization code grant_type
commit_message:
oidc: fix OpenID Connect authorization code grant_type

The current code is not working appropriately, as the authorization code
is a short-lived (the specification recommends less than 10 minutes) and
single use code, so it cannot be reused (if reused, the specification
states that all tokens obtained with the original code should be
revoked). Therefore, if we are implementing the authorization code grant
type we should follow the complete flow, that is:

1. obtain an authz code from the authz endpoint.
2. exchange the authz code with the token endpoint to get an access
   token.
3. exchange the access token with keystone to obtain an keystone token.

However (1) requires that the user authenticates with the IdP, and
According to the OAUTH 2.0 specification [1]:

    The authorization code grant type is used to obtain both access
    tokens and refresh tokens and is optimized for confidential clients.
    Since this is a redirection-based flow, the client must be capable
    of interacting with the resource owner’s user-agent (typically a web
    browser) and capable of receiving incoming requests (via
    redirection) from the authorization server.

[1] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6749#section-4.1

So interacting with the user browser is expected. If it is not possible
to interact with the client in this way, then a different grant type
(like client_credentials (to be implemented)) should be used if
supported by the server.

In short, whenever we execute this authentication we need to fire up a
user-agent (browser) and we need to spawn a temporary local http server
where the request will be redirected so that we can get the returned
authorization code. Then, we can continue with the flow (i.e. obtaining
the access token and exchanging it with Keystone for a Keystone token).

Incidentally, the OpenID plugin does not accept the redirect_uri
argument anymore, as this is something internally managed by us, and
that the user should not provide.

Note that with the code as it is, the access token is not persisted, so
whenever the session ends it is lost. If a user makes 100 different
requests this implies that 100 browser windows or tabs will be opened.
A possible improvement for all OpenID Connect plugins is the persistence
of the access token so that it can be reused, and the implementation of
refresh tokens, instead of requiring authentication each time.

Closes-Bug: #1583961
Closes-Bug: #1496258

subject: Break optimize_db_test_loader into package and module level
commit_message:
Break optimize_db_test_loader into package and module level

This unittest-compatible load_tests function was not
well organized for package-level tests and was broken
for module-level usage; as in the case of module-level usage,
the "pattern" parameter was being passed, which was unexpected
since the Python 2.7 documentation for unittest claims it will
be None.  However, we are using subunit to run tests, which
uses the unittest2 library that achieves compatibility with
Python 3 - in Python 3, the documentation was changed here
to note that "pattern" may be present (and in fact it is).

Instead, break it into optimize_package_test_loader and
optimize_module_test_loader.  The former assumes placement
inside of __init__.py only and the latter assumes placement
inside of a specific module only.

The issue with this function was observed when trying to get
OptimisingTestSuite to work correctly with neutron; tests
would be duplicated due to the double-search.  In local testing
it was shown that the function could cause recursion overflows.

It has been observed that using this function at the module level
is of great use when running subsets of tests, since the package-level
load_tests function is not consulted unless the test run is package-wide.

subject: Fix signal handling for daemons with InternalClient
commit_message:
Fix signal handling for daemons with InternalClient

The intentional use of "bare except" handling in catch_errors and some
daemons to prevent propagation on unexpected errors that do not
inherit from Exception (like eventlet.Timeout) or even BaseException
(like old-style classes) has the side effect of spuriously "handling"
*expected* errors like when a signal handler raises SystemExit.

The signal handler installed in our Daemon is intended to ensure first
that the entire process group and any forked processes (like rsync's)
receive the SIGTERM signal and also that the process itself
terminates.

The use of sys.exit was not a concious grandiose plans for graceful
shutdown (like the running[0] = False trick that wsgi server parent
process do) - the desired behavior for SIGTERM is to stop - hard.

This change ensures the original goals and intentions of our signal
handler are fulfilled without the undesirable side effect that can
cause our daemons to confusingly log an expected message to stop as an
unexpected error, and start ignoring additional SIGTERM messages;
forcing our kind operators to resort to brutal process murder.

Closes-Bug: #1489209

(cherry picked from commit c2ce92a)

subject: Add IPManager class for handling IP addresses
commit_message:
Add IPManager class for handling IP addresses

This patch begins work on an 'IPManager' class that further decouples
IP/CIDR manipulation from the openstack-ansible configuration handling
logic.

With this patchset, a new implementation is provided and tested in
isolation, with integration into and replacement of existing code set
for follow up patchsets.

The aim is also to provide a working implementation based on a proposed
IP management API for use with plugins. The proposed API is provided as
the IPBasePlugin class, and generic expectations of the API are
documented there.

A few notable changes exist in the new IPManager class versus the
existing codebase:

    - The Queue.Queue class is not used, but rather a plain, randomized
    list. Reviewing the existing implementation, there does not appear
    to be a need to use the specialized queue class.

    - USED_IPS is moved into a set associated with a given IPManager
    object. The expectation is that dynamic_inventory.py will treat
    IPManager as a singleton, but this implementation allows for
    replacing that singleton in test cases, or using multiple instances
    in some other context.

While the lib/ip.py file is not intended to be executed, the python
shebang line was provided in order to comply with our tox linting
searches.

Change-Id: I06729ac2bc1688a39255f2c8ea0d14131b5c2560

subject: neutron-dhcp-agent generates thousands of interfaces on a failure
commit_message:
neutron-dhcp-agent generates thousands of interfaces on a failure

Currently the exists method in IpNetnsCommand class of the ip_lib
module determines whether the namespace 'exists' or not with the
output of the command: ip -o netns list.

As reported in the bug, there may be cases where there may be an
empty namespace file in /run/netns but the namespace may not
actually exist. In such cases the dhcp agent throws an error
which isn't currently handled. It may also result in many tap
interfaces getting generated.

This patch fixes the above bug by modifying the exist method
to additionally execute a command in the namespace:
ip netns exec <namespace> ip addr, in order to confirm that the
namespace does actually exist.

This handles the error thrown by add_device_to_namespace method
resulting from non-existent namespaces and also stops generating
lots of tap interfaces.

Have scenario tests use ipv4

The scenario tests currently use the first ip address (or in the
case of clusters, all) that is found. Unfortunately some datastores
don't support IPV6, so if a non-ipv4 ip is used, the test will fail.
Until all datastores support IPV6 (or we can come up with a strategy

so the tests have been changed to accomodate this.

subject: Fix race condition in cluster-show
commit_message:
Fix race condition in cluster-show

There is a race condition in showing a cluster wherein the
server gets the list of instances from the db and then iterates
over the list to get the server information. If a shrink
operation is in progress, it can happen that one of the
instances is no longer present when trying to retrieve
the server info, and this causes the show command to throw
a NotFound error.

This is now trapped and the 'missing' server excluded from the list.

Change-Id: I54edc4acac09ca2278f525c08ad0d87576f0549e
